Editor: Prof. I.K. Song. Phillips catalyst is one of the most significant industrial catalyst for polyolefin. Various modified methods have been developed to promote the polymerization activity and regulate properties of polyolefin, including vanadium-modification, sulfation-modification, etc. Vanadium-modified Phillips catalyst can produce bimodal polyethylene with sectional ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene to improve the mechanical property. Compared with traditional Phillips catalyst, sulfation-modified Phillips catalyst exhibits higher polymerization activity and wider molecular weight distribution. However, lack of knowledge still puzzles researchers in reduction, alkylation and modification for Phillips catalyst. In addition, complex chemical surrounding for heterogeneous catalyst is still a big challenge to carry out explicit analysis of this catalyst. In this work, fundamental insight into two modified methods towards Phillips catalyst has been garnered. The possible active metal centers existing on the surface of silica support and feasible precursors with reductant attaching on the chromium center were investigated. Moreover, based on two alkylation precursors with assistance of different alkyl aluminum, we proposed a probable six-membered ring mechanism through the Tischenko reaction with formation of methyl formate derivant. Interestingly, the addition of sulfur atom reduces energy barrier of chain propagation significantly. These results account for the advantages of vanadium-modification, sulfation-modification and cocatalyst for traditional Phillips catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Phillips catalyst Vanadium-modification Reduction Sulfation-modification 1 Introduction Phillips catalyst as a unique catalyst for industrial polyethylene production is responsible for nearly 10 million tons of commercial polyolefin production covering more than one thirds of high density polyethylene market. This well-known catalyst was first reported by Hogan and Banks in Phillips Petroleum Company in early 1950s [1,2]. It is still competitive among polyethylene catalyst due to its lower cost and good processability of polyethylene originating from broad molecular weight distribution. In addition, cocatalyst isn't essential for Phillips catalyst to carry out polymerization compared with Ziegler-Natta or metallocene catalysts [3–6]. Following phenomenon makes Phillips catalyst unique among all known polyolefin catalysts. (1) For Phillips catalyst, the most significant characteristic is the distinctive structure of produced PE such as bimodal molecular weight distribution with long or short chain branches. This property is beneficial for further post processing application, and multimetallic catalyst can realize it through ethylene homopolymerization in a single reactor. Modification of chemical environment around active center is usually utilized as a valid method to improve polymerization performance for both industrial and academic communities. (2) Compared with other metal polyolefin catalyst, Phillips catalyst can be directly activated without any cocatalyst. This cocatalyst-free property endows with value for industrial application. Nonetheless, cocatalyst can accelerate induction period and improve polymerization activity under a mild condition. This property heightens economic profits for industrialization. For economic perspective, Phillips catalyst has irreplaceable value among industrial polyethylene catalyst. Meanwhile, the existence of cocatalyst also has influence on the physical properties of polyolefin, but excess co-catalyst will do harm to the polymerization activity [7]. Chemical surrounding of metal sites is regarded as a significant factor for heterogeneous catalyst [8]. It is recognized that atoms located on the surface are stereochemically distinguishing and coordination of metallic center varies in specified range [9]. Different valence of metallic sites is surrounded with various chemical environment in the catalytic system. For traditional metal oxide catalyst, metal center is randomly incorporated into host lattices through impregnation, stirring, calcination, etc. As one of the most famous heterogeneous catalyst, Phillips catalyst produces high-density polyethylene featured with extremely broad molecular weight distribution [10]. This property also reflects that numerous categories of active chromium center exist in complex surface of amorphous silica carrier. These sites exhibit own typical sensibility towards ethylene, which results from microstructure of amorphous silica [11]. Because of their complexity and indiscernibility, active sites in Phillips catalyst have not been clearly and systematically investigated. Many researchers have concentrated on the characterization of active sites in Phillips catalyst. Some researchers deem that chromium center is covalently bound to surface of silica and CrVI site is original state of these chromium center in calcined Cr/SiO2 catalyst [12]. As was reported, CrVI-dioxo species could be reduced to CrII site for further alkylation along with a small amount of CrIII sites under condition of reductant. Meanwhile, only <10% of Cr sites are active under catalytic condition [13,14]. It is concluded that all chromium center is present as monochromate, some of which was used to be considered as bidentate form [15,16]. These investigations have promoted evolution of Phillips catalyst in the past few years. Industrial improvement also has been obtained due to reform of original composition. Many modification methods were utilized to improve performance of Phillips catalyst, including molybdenum-modification, fluoride-modification, vanadium-modification, titanium-modification, sulfation-modification etc. These modified methods give different enhancement towards polymerization performance and expand application field of polyolefin [17–20]. It also brings in extra active center and adjusts Lewis acidity of chromium center. Chemical modifications of metallic catalyst with aluminum atom, fluoride atom, vanadium atom, titanium atom and sulfur atom have been successfully industrialized [13,21,22]. Terano and group member once carried out a series of Phillips-type bimetallic catalysts synthesis to improve the machinability of polyolefin materials [23]. When electron density of chromium center was decreased with addition of second metallic or non-metallic atom, polyethylene can be produced with a higher activity, especially for modification of acidic group. Ammonium sulfate can be utilized to treat Cr/silica via depositing bits of sulfur atom on the surface of silica in order to realize sulfation-modification. For this modification, molecular weight distribution often turns to lower side with higher activity and resultant polymer has a higher melt index. The sulfate-associated species are more quickly activated than other sites due to the formation of new acidic site. Whereas with complex surface structure of support, the real active center for Phillips catalyst is still unclear. Researchers also attempt to use characterization technique to investigate initiation and alkylation for this important industrial catalyst. However, microstructures surrounding chromium center seldom catch researcher's attention, but these microstructures possibly have influence on reduction and alkylation for heterogeneous catalyst. Herein, we aim to elucidate two different industrial modification of traditional Phillips catalyst in order to give a deeper understanding on the electronic effect of metallic center or non-metallic center. Methyl formate derivant is proposed as the product through the Tischenko reaction for initiation of cocatalyst-free Phillips catalyst. Simultaneously, the addition of alkyl aluminum is able to generate new active centers, which accelerates the induction period and regulates molecular weight distribution. We also investigated the interaction between chromium center and sulfur atom compared with traditional Phillips catalyst. 2 Computational details All DFT calculations were carried out with the Gaussian 09 program package [24]. Geometry optimization was performed without any symmetry constraint by using B3LYP functional, in combination with the split valence double-zeta basis set def2-SVP for all atoms [25–27]. The D3 version of Grimme's dispersion was incorporated into the geometry optimizations. In addition, harmonic vibrational frequency calculation was used to confirm if structures have been properly optimized. The transition state was further verified through a full intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculation [28,29]. Gibbs free energy correction was calculated at the experimental conditions (T = 353.15 K, p = 5 atm). Accordingly, high-level single-point energy calculations were performed for each optimized structures with the B3LYP functional and a large triple-zeta basis set def2-TZVP [30]. Solvation energies were obtained with the Truhlar's SMD solvation model, using n-heptane as the model solvent [31]. Therefore, the relative free energy was calculated using the following equation: Δ G A = Δ E e l e c + Δ E t h e r m a l − T Δ S + Δ G s o l v where ΔG is the free energy change relative to the separated reactants for species A; ΔEelec is the total electronic energy change calculated at B3LYP/def2-TZVP level; ΔEthermal is the total internal thermal energy change including the contributions due to translation, rotational, and vibrational motions; ΔS is the total solute entropy change; and ΔGsolv is the solvation free energy change in a specific solvent. Three different chromium centers are presented in Fig. 1 and the distinction between these catalyst models depends on the surface structure of heterogeneous catalyst, including interaction of metallic or nonmetallic atoms. In this part, Model A, B and C respectively represent vanadium-modified Phillips catalyst, traditional Phillips catalyst and Phillips catalyst surrounded with SiOSi bond (Table S1 in Supporting Information). During calcination, ammonium sulfate decomposes and evaporates, and then the products react with the silica surface. Bond formation of sulfur atom in heterogeneous catalyst is multiple due to the uneven distribution. Model D and Model E are designed to make comparison between traditional Phillips catalyst and sulfation-modified Phillips catalyst. We take classic six-membered ring model to simplify the effect of surrounding environment and focus on the electronic effect of sulfur atom. High valence of sulfur atom takes place of one silicon atom in six membered ring. For Model B-S and Model C-S, the sulfur atom exists in the adjacent six membered silica ring, which differs from the bonding forms in Model D. 3 Results and discussion For heterogeneous catalyst, the complexity of surface makes the research challenging to analyze the real active center during polymerization. Espelid and Børve first constructed mononuclear and dinuclear cluster models in Phillips catalyst [33,34]. Over the last few years, many researchers, who utilized cluster model to investigate Phillips catalyst, has achieved a substantial progress [17,35–37]. The catalyst model in Handzlik's work has large steric effect in subjacent silica model. Cluster models of the chromium surface species used in his work were developed based on the β-cristobalite framework and they were fully relaxed to allow for the amorphous nature of the support. However, this steric effect has finite influence on chromium center for upward ethylene coordination and insertion. We suppose that the oxygen group surrounding chromium center is a key factor for reduction and propagation as well. According to previous research, vanadium-modified chromium polyethylene catalyst exhibits higher homopolymerization activity than single chromium catalyst [38]. Synergistic effect between vanadium center and chromium center is deemed as the main reason for this phenomenon. Cavallo and group member conclude that buried volume gives a determination of space occupied by ligand in the first coordination sphere of metal, and the correlation between the %VBur of the precursors and the DFT-calculated ΔG of propagation versus termination exhibits a linear relation [39]. The geometrical structure of three active center is partially similar on the basis of steric hindrance (buried volume %VBur: 67.3 for Model A, 66.6 for Model B, 75.2 for Model C, as shown in Fig. 1). This result indicates that the existence of SiOSi bond leads to the preference of chain transfer. In the meantime, the %VBur of Model B and Model A is not significantly different. It also demonstrates that the steric hindrances of vanadium atom has limited influence on Phillips catalyst and the distance between two metallic center in Model A isn't relatively close owing to the homodisperse of vanadium atom in this system. Compared with vanadium-modified active center, nucleophilic property of SiOSi bond leads to the considerable interaction of oxygen atom and chromium atom. The bulkiness also goes against the insertion for olefins and complex surface appearance of silica-gel carrier is the main reason for the formation of multiple active center resulting in wide molecular weight distribution of polyolefin. It clearly shows that the distance between chromium atoms and other nonchromium atoms decreases gradually at high spin multiplicity surfaces (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Singlet is the ground spin state for all three catalyst models, and the relative Gibbs free energy increases dramatically when these models are optimized at high spin multiplicities. This phenomenon has been reported in our previous work, which results in an increase of bond length between metal atom and oxygen atom generating unstable chromium oxide species [40]. The frontier molecular orbitals of three active center have the ‘right’ unoccupied orbital on CrO bond to accept the electron from olefins in order to realize reduction (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). 3.1 Reduction and alkylation with assistance of ethylene The first CrC bond in Phillips catalyst is not present in the precatalyst and it can't originate from alkylating activator without addition of any cocatalyst. Ethylene is the only source of the first CrC bond or CrH bond [41]. Groppo and group member once reported possible existence of methylformate in the reduction of Phillips catalyst through the Tischenko reaction [42,43]. Thus, we put forward the following mechanism to investigate the formation of methylformate. Products of both routes possess Cr-H bond, which is beneficial to realize alkylation. We can see that vanadium-modified Phillips catalyst is easier to make interaction with ethylene from Table 1 (3.7 kcal mol−1 for 1A2, 5.3 kcal mol−1 for 1B2 and 11.6 kcal mol−1 for 1C2). Variation of spin multiplicity takes place in the next reaction in order to maintain lowest Gibbs free energy (-23.3 kcal mol−1 for 3A2, -23.2 kcal mol−1 for 3B2, -27.2 kcal mol−1 for 3C2). It is described that quintet state is the ground state for reduced Phillips catalyst when small gas molecular is absorbed on chromium center [44]. For formaldehyde, it is possible to generate ester derivant through Tischenko reaction. McDaniel also reports the possible carboxylate species resulting from reduction of monochromate. They conclude that oxygenate ligands may strongly adhere in polymerization system [45,46]. On this basis, we designed two types of ester derivant with interaction with active chromium center in Fig. 2 and detailed comparison has been listed in Fig. 3 . Both six-membered ring and five-membered ring have strain ring for geometric structure. In terms of Gibbs free energy, Route 1 has certain advantages compared with Route 2. The generation of free radical also makes Route 2 less stable and the breaking of CrO bond seems to be essential for reduction. The energy barrier for three active center is 21.0 kcal mol−1 for Model A, 21.5 kcal mol−1 for Model B, and 19.1 kcal mol−1 for Model C, respectively. Geometric structures of transition state 4-5aTS are depicted in Fig. 4 . The distances between chromium atom and hydrogen atom over these models are almost uniform (1.69 Å for Cr⋯H and 2.05 Å for Cr⋯O). The most obvious distinction is the distance between hydrogen atom and carbon atom over three models (1.83 Å for Model A, 1.88 Å for Model B and 1.87 Å for Model C). The existence of SiOSi bond possibly increases Gibbs free energy of initiatory 5C4a due to the steric effect and eventually decreases activation energy. The fact that Gibbs free energy of vanadium-modified Phillips catalyst significantly decreases also demonstrates the existence of synergistic effect between vanadium center and chromium center is valid. For supported CrV bimetallic catalyst, its activity is slightly higher than that of monometallic catalyst and the polyethylene in bimetallic system exhibited wider molecular weight distribution. Synergistic effect of vanadium atom promotes ethylene molecular to interact with CrO bond and steric hindrance of carrier has the adverse effect during this process. Although the conversion from species 4a to 5a is endergonic, the increase of Gibbs free energy is acceptable compared with chain propagation of alkylated Phillips catalyst. The species 5a seems to be an active intermediate state beneficial for further chain propagation. Chain propagation is indispensable for ethylene polymerization, which controls molecular weight and branching coefficient of polyolefin. Different metallic centers have their own responding towards olefin and these characteristics of catalyst have enriched the properties of polymer material, including chain walking, copolymerization with polar monomer, etc [47–50]. McDaniel proposed that the formation of starting species originates from a methyl group and “H-donor compound” stays on Cr site before alkylation [51]. The mechanism of alkylation process is presented through making comparison between Cr-H insertion and CrC insertion in Fig. 5 . The first ethylene insertion occurs with relatively low activation energy for Cr–H site (2.0 kcal mol−1 for Model A, 3.6 kcal mol−1 for Model B and 2.3 kcal mol−1 for Model C from Table S2 in the Supporting Information). When the terminal group is alkyl function group, energy barrier for the second ethylene insertion increases significantly (10.0 kcal mol−1 for Model A, 12.6 kcal mol−1 for Model B, and 15.5 kcal mol−1 for Model C). Thus, ethylene insertion into CrC bond is the rate-determining step for alkylation. Among three models, vanadium-modified Phillips catalyst maintains the lowest activation energy for ethylene insertion with addition of vanadium center. Model B and Model C possess the similar activation energy according to Fig. 5. It illustrates that the chromium center adjacent to vanadium center is prior to interact with ethylene compared with monochromium center and the existence of SiOSi bond makes alkylation more endergonic. The detailed Gibbs free energy for Route 2 are listed in Table S3 in the Supporting Information. The energy barrier of the first ethylene insertion for Route 2 is about 3.0 kcal mol−1 higher than that for Route 1. Similarly, the energy barrier of the second ethylene insertion for Route 2 is about 10.0 kcal mol−1 higher than that for Route 1 (Route 2: 19.3 kcal mol−1 for Model A, 22.9 kcal mol−1 for Model B, 25.8 kcal mol−1 for Model C). To sum up, ethylene insertion for free radical is more endergonic and itself is unstable during polymerization. The most confusing problem for Phillips catalyst is how the first alkyl chain generates. Although the existence of surrounding oxygen group slightly increases energy barrier of transition state compared with that in Handzlik's work. For chromium center with active Cr–H bond, alkylation seems to be much more reasonable for ethylene insertion into Cr–H bond compared with ‘bare’ chromium center. 3.2 Reduction and alkylation with assistance of alkyl aluminum Alkyl aluminum is considered as one of industrial activator, which can realize alkylation with direct transfer to the metal center. Therefore, induction period is always shortened when cocatalyst is added into catalytic system. The addition of alkyl aluminum in polymerization accelerates the reaction rate and assists alkyl exchange as well. Meanwhile, cocatalyst can control the molecular weight distribution to a certain degree via participating the reaction process [52]. Nonetheless, different categories of alkyl aluminum have respective influence on the polymerization yield [53]. In this part, we focus on the interaction between cocatalyst and the chromium center. In general, trimethylaluminum (TMA) is not a preferred choice as cocatalyst for Phillips catalyst due to its poor polymerization activity. As is reported, triethyl aluminum (TEA) and triisobutyl aluminum (TiBA) are the proper candidates for this catalyst [54]. When alkyl group possesses longer carbon chain among above three kinds of cocatalyst, Phillips catalyst would exhibit a better performance on polymerization activity. On the contrast of TMA, TiBA is able to maintain monomer form during polymerization. Meanwhile, dimer form accounts for the majority of TMA in organic solvent system (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information) [55]. We put forward the probable mechanism for Cr(VI) site to study the reduction and alkylation process with assistance of TiBA in Fig. 6 . Gibbs free energy of two alkyl precursors (structure 11 and structure 13) are listed in Table 2 . Acting spot of cocatalyst determines the final structure of precursor. In terms of Gibbs free energy, structure 13 is more stable than structure 11(-114.2 kcal mol−1 for 5A13, -85.0 kcal mol−1 for 5B13, -83.4 kcal mol−1 for 5C13). Compared with structure 11, unoccupied orbital on chromium center of structure 13 is also beneficial for π electron donation from ethylene molecule. When TiBA is taken as cocatalyst, Gibbs free energy of vanadium-modified Phillips catalyst decreases more obviously than traditional Phillips catalyst in quintet state. It means that synergistic effect between vanadium center and chromium center can promote interaction with cocatalyst. In terms of strongly reductive TMA, overreductive chromium center may be generated, which exhibits poor polymerization activity and certain reducibility. 3.3 Sulfation-modified Phillips catalyst Brønsted acid also can be used to treat Cr/silica catalyst, including sulfate, phosphate and fluoride. Ammonium sulfate is one of proper precursors to incorporate sulfur atom. It decomposes gradually during calcination and small amount of sulfur atom remaining in the catalyst system can be detected [56]. In general, addition of Brønsted acid in metallic catalyst is considered as an efficient method to improve the performance of polymerization and it is derived from the metal center with high electron deficiency on the surface of carrier. The modification method not only is beneficial to generate new active center but also increases the molecular weight distribution on the low molecular weight part. The sulfate-associated species can be activated more quickly than other sites and was possibly short lived as well. It is significative to construct model of sulfation-modified catalyst to investigate its intricate effect (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information). NBO charge on chromium center with sulfation treated is much higher than that without sulfation treated for Model B and Model C. With the increase of spin multiplicity for sulfation-modified Phillips catalyst, energy will gradually increase and its trend is similar to that of Phillips catalyst in Table 3 . The distinction of Gibbs free energy is more conspicuous in higher spin multiplicity. Singlet state is the ground state for the unreduced Cr(VI) Phillips catalyst and it is essential to change the spin multiplicity from singlet state to high spin state for further chain propagation. Sulfation-modified models is less energy-demanding to variate spin multiplicity, which means that it is much easier for sulfation-modified Phillips catalyst to carry out reduction and ethylene coordination. In terms of NBO charge, the existence of sulfur atom can improve the metallic property for Model B-S and Model C-S. In the meantime, the limited difference between Model B and Model C demonstrates that existence of sulfur atom is more meaningful than surrounding SiOSi bond. We make comparison for propagation between sulfation-modified Phillips catalyst and traditional Phillips catalyst in Fig. 7 . Energy barrier of the first ethylene insertion on sulfation-modified catalyst is higher than that of untreated catalyst according to Table S4 in the Supporting Information (ΔGins5 = 21.0 kcal mol−1 for Model B-S vs. ΔGins5 = 19.9 kcal mol−1 for Model B; ΔGins5 = 21.5 kcal mol−1 for Model C-S vs. ΔGins5 = 20.6 kcal mol−1 for Model C). For the second ethylene insertion, the gaps between two catalyst is ca. 4.0 kcal mol−1 (ΔGins6 = 22.3 kcal mol−1 for Model B-S vs. ΔGins6 = 18.9 kcal mol−1 for Model B; ΔGins6 = 23.6 kcal mol−1 for Model C-S vs. ΔGins6 = 19.2 kcal mol−1 for Model C). To some extent, sulfation-modification is able to increase the energy barrier of ethylene insertion in this bonding form. Meanwhile, it also does harm to the coordination of ethylene, which leads to temporarily ascending coordination energy of ethylene (11.8 kcal mol−1 for Model B-S and 10.5 kcal mol−1 for Model C-S). Overall, the existence of sulfur atom which doesn't have direct interaction with chromium center isn't beneficial for ethylene insertion. When surrounding oxygen atom on sulfation is close to chromium center, competitive effect between ethylene and sulfation would take place. Sulfur atom in Model D has the direct interaction with chromium center in Fig. 8 and the variation of Gibbs free energy between singlet state and quintet state is less endergonic than other sulfation-modification according to Table 3. The energy barrier of ethylene insertion for Model D is ca. 15.5 kcal mol−1, which is lower than that for Model E without sulfation-modification (Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). In Table S5, Gibbs free energy change from species 11 to 55a for Model D is ca. 6.8 kcal mol−1 lower than that for Model E. It almost halves the energy increase from 1E1 to 5E5a. This calculation result also demonstrates that sulfur addition is beneficial for the generation of the active species. There are different bonding forms of sulfation-modification appearing on the surface of silica gel. Model D refers to the sites activated quickly and other sulfation-modified model probably corresponds to the short-lived sites. With propagation of alkyl chain on active center, it seems to be more difficult for ethylene coordination on Model B-S and Model C-S due to the competitive effect. According to the NBO charge, the electropositivity of metallic center doesn't always play the key role in polymerization and coordination surrounding of active center is also principal element for the two sulfation-modified methods. The result of these different modified models also coincides with previous experimental phenomenon [10,22]. 4 Conclusion Detailed DFT study on the vanadium-modified Phillips catalyst and sulfation-modified Phillips catalyst have been carried out to investigate the influence on this important industrial catalyst. For vanadium-modified Phillips catalyst, the synergistic effect between vanadium center and chromium center effectively reduces the overall Gibbs free energy, which enhances polymerization activity of bimetallic catalyst compared with monometallic catalyst. We put forward the probable mechanism with formation of methyl formate derivant attached on chromium center following six-membered ring and five-membered ring. Compared with six-membered ring mechanism, five-membered ring mechanism showed higher activation energy due to the formation of free radical. On the basis of Cr-H precursor, the first ethylene insertion is much easier to carry out and acting spot of cocatalyst is also vital for polymerization. There are many sulfation-modified sites on the surface of silica, which depends on the bonding forms. Sulfation-modified Model D can decrease activation energy of ethylene insertion significantly compared with traditional Phillips catalyst. Reduction and alkylation seem to be easily realized on this site. Thus, coordination environment of chromium center is also principal factor for sulfation-modification rather than the charge on active center. This work is helpful to understand the mechanism of two meaningful modified method and answer some unique natural character of Phillips catalyst. Credit Author Statement Kaimin Liu. coredata.dc:description: Phillips catalyst is one of the most significant industrial catalyst for polyolefin. Various modified methods have been developed to promote the polymerization activity and regulate properties of polyolefin, including vanadium-modification, sulfation-modification, etc. Vanadium-modified Phillips catalyst can produce bimodal polyethylene with sectional ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene to improve the mechanical property. Compared with traditional Phillips catalyst, sulfation-modified Phillips catalyst exhibits higher polymerization activity and wider molecular weight distribution. However, lack of knowledge still puzzles researchers in reduction, alkylation and modification for Phillips catalyst. In addition, complex chemical surrounding for heterogeneous catalyst is still a big challenge to carry out explicit analysis of this catalyst. In this work, fundamental insight into two modified methods towards Phillips catalyst has been garnered. The possible active metal centers existing on the surface of silica support and feasible precursors with reductant attaching on the chromium center were investigated. Moreover, based on two alkylation precursors with assistance of different alkyl aluminum, we proposed a probable six-membered ring mechanism through the Tischenko reaction with formation of methyl formate derivant. Interestingly, the addition of sulfur atom reduces energy barrier of chain propagation significantly. These results account for the advantages of vanadium-modification, sulfation-modification and cocatalyst for traditional Phillips catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanistic study of vanadium-modified and sulfation-modified Phillips catalyst
